revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = List of Taínos |image = [[File:Estatua de Agüeybaná II, El Bravo, en el Parque Monumento a Agüeybaná II, El Bravo, en Ponce, Puerto Rico (DSC02672C).jpg|150px]] |caption = Statue of [[Agüeybaná II]], "El Bravo", in [[Ponce, Puerto Rico]] |regions = Puerto Rico, Hispaniola, Cuba, Bahamas, Jamaica |ref3 = |languages = [[Taíno language]], later Spanish, English, Creole |religions = [[#Religion|Indigenous]] |related = }}
This is a '''list of known Taínos''', some of which were ''caciques'' (male and female [[tribal chief]]s). Their names are in ascending alphabetical order and the table may be re-sorted by clicking on the arrows in the column header cells.
The [[Taínos]] were the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] inhabitants of the [[Bahamas]], [[Greater Antilles]], and some of the [[Lesser Antilles]] – especially in [[Guadeloupe]], [[Dominica]] and [[Martinique]]. The Taínos ("Taíno" means "relatives"), unlike the [[Island Caribs|Caribs]] (who practiced regular raids on other groups), were peaceful seafaring people and distant relatives of the [[Arawak peoples|Arawak]] people of South America.<ref>Rouse, p. 5., Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref>
Taíno society was divided into two classes: ''Nitainos'' (nobles) and the ''Naborias'' (commoners). Both were governed by chiefs known as ''caciques'', who were the maximum authority in a ''Yucayeque'' (village). The chiefs were advised by priest-healers known as ''Bohiques'' and the ''Nitaynos'', which is how the elders and warriors were known.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmuseo.org/taino/caciques.html |title=Caciques, nobles and their regalia |accessdate=2006-11-09 |work= |publisher=elmuseo.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061009090513/http://elmuseo.org/taino/caciques.html |archivedate=2006-10-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
This is an incomplete list, which may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. Anyone can help by expanding it with reliably sourced entries.
{{clr}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 0 auto" ! style="text-align: left" | Portrait ! style="text-align: left" | Name ! style="text-align: left" | Remarks |- | | [[Abey]] | Cacique (Chief) of yucayeque-(village) in the area of Abeyno [[Salinas, Puerto Rico]].<ref>[http://www.prfrogui.com/home/Salinas.htm Salinas]</ref> |- | | [[Acanorex]] | Cacique of Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya) (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico">[http://www.linktopr.com/diccionario.html Classics of Puerto Rico, second edition 1972, compiled by Puerto Rican historian Dr. Cayetano Coll Y Toste of the "Royal Academy of History"], Retrieved September 20, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811210500/http://www.linktopr.com/diccionario.html |date=August 11, 2007 }}</ref> |- |<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Agueybana3.jpg|90px]] --> | [[Agüeybaná (The Great Sun)|Agüeybaná]] (The Great Sun) | Cacique whose name means "The Great Sun" was "Supreme Cacique" in [[Puerto Rico]] who welcomed Juan Ponce de León and the conquistadors. His yucayeque was on the Guayanilla Bay area. He was also known as '''Guaybana'''<ref>[http://www.salboricua.com/history.htm History of Puerto Rico], Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | [[Image:Estatua de Agüeybaná II, El Bravo, en el Parque Monumento a Agüeybaná II, El Bravo, en Ponce, Puerto Rico (DSC02672C).jpg|90px]] |[[Agüeybaná II]] (The Brave) | Cacique Agüeybaná's brother. Agüeybaná II, who was also known as Güeybaná and Guaybana II, led the Taíno rebellion of 1511 in Puerto Rico against the Spanish settlers.<ref>[http://www.pcmle.org/EM/article.php3?id_article=258 LA REBELIÓN DEL CACIQUE AGUEYBANA II (The revolt of the Cacique Agüeybaná II)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206012148/http://www.pcmle.org/EM/article.php3?id_article=258 |date=2012-02-06 }}, Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Alonso]] | Minor Cacique of (Otoao) [[Utuado, Puerto Rico]].<ref name="Caciques">[http://www.proyectosalonhogar.com/Enciclopedia_Ilustrada/Caciques.htm ''Caciques'']. La Gran Enciclopedia Ilustrada del Proyecto Salón Hogar. Accessed on September 18, 2007.</ref> |- | | [[Amanex]] | Cacique of Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya) (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | | [[Ameyro]] | Cacique of [[Jamaica]], who lived on the eastern extremity of the island. He and [[Diego Mendez]] became great friends, exchanged names, which is a kind of token of brotherhood (Guatiao). Mendez engaged him to furnish provisions to his ships. He then bought an excellent canoe from the cacique, for which he gave a splendid brass basin, a short frock or cassock, and one of the two shirts which formed his stock of linen. The cacique furnished him with six Indians to navigate his bark, and they parted mutually well pleased.<ref>http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/18268?c=read&page=227</ref> |- | |[[Anacaona]] | Cacica of [[Hispaniola|Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya)]]. Wife of Caonabo, the Cacique of Maguana and sister of Cacique Bohechío, when his brother died, she became the Cacica of Jaragua. Reported to have had friendly encounters with escaped slaves.<ref>[http://haitisupport.gn.apc.org/10_fam_main.html#an Anacaona]</ref> |- | | [[Aramaná]] | Cacique around Coa (Toa) river in Puerto Rico.<ref name="Caciques" /> |- | | [[Aramoca]] | Cacique Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya) (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | |[[Arasibo]] | Cacique of yucayeque in the area of Río Abacoa ([[Río Grande de Arecibo]]) [[Arecibo, Puerto Rico]].<ref>[http://www.arecibolighthouse.com/menuss/poblado.htm Arasibo Indian Village], Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Ayamuynuex]] | Cacique of Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya) (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | | [[Aymamón]] | Cacique of yucayeque around [[Río Culebrinas|Culebrinas]] river in Puerto Rico. Puerto Rican anthropologist [[Ricardo Alegría]] suggests that the proper pronunciation and name of the cacique was Aymaco, with Aymamón being a way of designating the cacique that ruled over the region called Aymamio, or possibly just a misunderstanding of the name's adequate pronunciation. However, historical documents have traditionally used the name Aymamón. He is known for having ordered the kidnapping of the son of Spaniard Pedro Xuarez. He called for a game at the batey among his subjects and offered as prize the honor of burning the Spaniard alive and hence proving their mortality and vincibility. However, the Spanish found out about the plan and Captain Salazar was sent to rescue the young Spaniard. In the subsequent battle, the son of Pedro Xuarez was rescued and Aymaco wounded. While healing, Aymaco called on Salazar to exchange names and offer peace. Despite his peace offering, he later participated in the Taíno Rebellion of 1511 which was also crushed.<ref name="Caciques" /> |- | | [[Ayraguay]] | Cacique of Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya) (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | | [[Bagnamanay]] | Cacique of the [[Caguas, Puerto Rico]] area.<ref name="Bagnamanay">[http://proyectosadnhispanos.bravehost.com/ProyectoADNPRtaino.html The Hispanic and Geographic DNA Projects] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060117083150/http://proyectosadnhispanos.bravehost.com/ProyectoADNPRtaino.html |date=2006-01-17 }}, Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Baguanao]] | Cacique of [[Matanzas, Cuba]] Father of Cibayara<ref name="Baguanao">[http://www.tvyumuri.icrt.cu/leyendas-matanceras/2482-canimao.html Retrieved October 22, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620100721/http://www.tvyumuri.icrt.cu/leyendas-matanceras/2482-canimao.html |date=June 20, 2012 }}</ref> |- | | [[Biautex]] | Cacique of Hispaniola (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | | [[Bojékio]] or [[Bohechio]] | Cacique elder in Hispaniola brother of [[Anacaona]]cacica of Xaragua(In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | | [[Brizuela]] | Cacique of [[Baitiquirí]], [[Cuba]].<ref name="Brizuela">[http://www.lademajagua.co.cu/bayamo.htm La Demajagua] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114063001/http://www.lademajagua.co.cu/bayamo.htm |date=2007-11-14 }}, Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Cacicaná]] | Cacique of Cueybá [[Cuba]] Provided food and shelter to [[Alonso de Ojeda]] who was shipwrecked on the Island of [[Cuba]] he was accompanied by seventy men and was seeking help. The pirate Bernardino de Talavera took Ojeda prisoner. A hurricane struck Talaveras ship and Talavera made amends and helped each other, despite their efforts the ship was shipwrecked at Jagua, [[Sancti Spíritus]], on the south coast of [[Cuba]]. Ojeda decided to travel along the coast on foot with Talavera and his men in order to reach [[Maisí]] Point from where they would be able to get to Hispaniola. However, the party faced a number of difficulties en route and half of the men died of hunger, illness or other hardships that they met along the way. The sole possession remaining to Ojeda was an image of the [[Virgin Mary]], which he had carried with him since he left [[Spain]]. He made a promise on this image that he would build a church dedicated to her in the first village that he reached where he was given hospitality. A little later, and with only a dozen men and the pirate Talavera still surviving, he arrived in the district of Cueybá where the chief Cacicaná provided food and shelter. Ojeda was true to his word and he built a small hermitage to the Virgin in the village, which was venerated by the local people. The party was rescued by [[Pánfilo de Narváez]] and taken to [[Jamaica]], where Talavera was imprisoned for piracy. From [[Jamaica]] Ojeda returned to Hispaniola where he learned that [[Fernández de Enciso]] had been able to relieve the colonists who had stayed in San Sebastián modern day Municipality of [[Necoclí]] in the subregion [[Urabá Antioquia|Urabá]] in the department [[Antioquia Department|Antioquia]], [[Colombia]].<ref>[[Alonso de Ojeda]]</ref> |- | | [[Cacimar]] | Cacique of Caribe One of the last Cacique to fight against the Spanish invadors of the island.<ref>[http://www.topuertorico.org/city/luquillo.shtml Luquilo], Retrieved November 2, 2008</ref> |- | | [[Mabey (chief)|Mabey]] | Cacique of Ayiti or Quisqueya (Kiskeya), had arrived with Cacique [[Hatuey]] fleeing the Spanish on the neighboring island of [[La Hispaniola]], pursued by the Spanish arrived at the Güinía Gold mines, of what is now the province of [[Villa Clara, Cuba]] in the municipality of [[Manicaragua]] stirring up a rebellion, the Spanish to prevent the rebellion intensified the search of Mabey. The center of operations of Cacique Mabey against the Spanish were at the foot of a hill called La Degollada. In the battle through the mountains, Taino rebels Baconao & Abama (Husband and wife) were killed. Mabey was surrounded and cornered at the edge of a cliff where he and Gálvez fought hand-to-hand the battle lasted various minutes, Gálvez's servant, an ambitious and cruel man saw the possibility of running away with treasure and pretending that he was helping Gálvez pushed both of them down the cliff where they fell to their death. The Spanish arrived with a group of captured Indians found out through Bacanao small daughter who was embracing the body of her dead mother (Abama), the truth about the crime. Gálvez's servant was taken prisoner as so were the Taino rebels and Baconao's Daughter. The Spanish buried Gálvez and left Mabey's cadaver to rot and be eaten by vultures. They then led the procession of indigenous prisoners to the presence of Capitan Vasco de Porcallo, which he ordered to the gallows. There, in the Loma de la Cruz, which bisects the town Güinía neighborhoods, the 12 Indians were hanged, the traitor (Gálvez's servant) was hung by his feet and shot in that position. There is an old legend of the town that on certain occasions people see a blue light on the scene where these events took place, preceded by a woman's scream.<ref>[http://www.ecured.cu/index.php/G%C3%BCin%C3%ADa_de_Miranda]</ref> |- | | [[Mabodomaca]] | Cacique in the north west region near Guajataca.<ref>[http://www.nyboricua.com/boricua.htm ''Taíno Borincano''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070925132137/http://www.nyboricua.com/boricua.htm |date=2007-09-25 }}. village. When he landed, however, he saw eleven corpses of his men on the beach and discovered that La Navidad had been destroyed.<ref name="www27.us.archive.org"/> |- | | [[Mayobanex]] | Cacique of Hispaniola of the Ciguayo region.<ref>http://www.encaribe.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1151:mayobanex&catid=106:historia&Itemid=139{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> |- | | [[Naguabo]] |Cacique near the municipality of [[Naguabo, Puerto Rico]].<ref>[http://www.prfrogui.com/home/naguabo.htm Naguabo-Los Enchumbaos], Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Nibagua]] |Cacique of Hispaniola (In the area now called Haiti)<ref name="Clasico"/> |- | | [[Ornofay]] | Cacique of the Jaragueyal region what today now is known as [[Ciego de Ávila, Cuba]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.100cia.cu/?q=ornofay |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130210062426/http://www.100cia.cu/?q=ornofay |archivedate=2013-02-10 |df= }}, Retrieved October 22, 2012</ref> |- |<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Guanin of Chief Orocobix.jpg|90px]] --> | [[Orocobix]] |Cacique of the Jatibonicu region that covering the municipalities of Orocovis, Aibonito, Barranquitas, Morovis and Corozal in [[Puerto Rico]].<ref>[http://www.linktopr.com/orocovis.html Orocovis... Corazón de Puerto Rico], Retrieved September 19, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012011012/http://www.linktopr.com/orocovis.html |date=October 12, 2007 }}</ref> For Further details on the tribe please see: <http://www.facebook.com/Jatibonicu.Taino> <https://web.archive.org/web/20170611102145/http://taino-tribe-gov.org/ |- | | [[Tínima]] |Cacique Princess of [[Camagüey, Cuba]] and Daughter of Cacique [[Camagüebax]], Married to Captain Vasco Porcallo de Figueroa founder of the villa Sancti Spíritus y de Sabaneque.<ref>[http://en.calameo.com/read/000345214d171d7bd2cee Cuba], Retrieved October 22, 2012</ref> |- | |[[Urayoán]] |Cacique of "Yucayeque del Yagüeka or Yagueca", who ordered the drowning of [[Diego Salcedo (soldier)|Diego Salcedo]].<ref>[http://www.cosmos.ne.jp/~miyagawa/nagocnet/data/prhistory.html Puerto Rico] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060222012007/http://www.cosmos.ne.jp/~miyagawa/nagocnet/data/prhistory.html |date=2006-02-22 }}, Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Yacagüex]] |Cacique of Cuba<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wssTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA424&lpg=PA424&dq=manatiguahuraguana&source=bl&ots=RGJpJ-DjGw&sig=6SxKVqUaKFMdtGYuOA_TS4mAPhU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=aRCKULbAHJGO8wTa4YGgDQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=manatiguahuraguana&f=false]</ref> |- | | [[Yacahüey]] |Cacique from Yucayo reigned over Havana and Matanzas, [[Cuba]]. Also Known as: Yaguacayo, Yaguacayex, Yacayeo, Yucayonex<ref name="Diccionario"/> |- | | [[Yahíma]] |Daughter of the Cacique Jibacoa of Cuba<ref>{{cite web |url=http://espanol.cuba.com/cuba_detail_1913_la_leyenda_majibacoa_.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113005200/http://espanol.cuba.com/cuba_detail_1913_la_leyenda_majibacoa_.html |archivedate=2013-11-13 |df= }}</ref> |- | | [[Yaureibo]] |Cacique and brother of Cacique Cacimar on the island of Bieques (Vieques). He died in 1514, during a surprise attack by the Spaniards as he readied his men to attack the mainland to avenge his brother Cacimar's death.<ref name="Cacimar"/> |- | | [[Yuisa]] (Luisa) |Cacica in the region near [[Loíza, Puerto Rico]] who was baptized by the Spaniards. She died in 1515, during a Carib raid on her land. She married a Spanish man called Pedro Mexias.<ref>[http://www.elyunque.com/loiza.htm The Last Taino Queen], Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |- | | [[Yuquibo]] |Cacique who ruled in the region of Luquillo. Known as Loquillo (Crazy One) by the Spaniards due to his constant attacks on the Conquistadors. The town of [[Luquillo, Puerto Rico]] is named for him.<ref>[http://www.alfredcarrada.org/notes8.html the Dictionary of the Taino Lanjuage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219192148/http://alfredcarrada.org/notes8.html |date=2009-02-19 }}, Retrieved September 19, 2007</ref> |}
==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Cuba|Dominican Republic|Haiti|Bahamas|Jamaica}} *[[List of Puerto Ricans#Taínos|List of Notable Puerto Ricans]] *[[List of Cubans|List of Notable Cubans]] *[[List of people from the Dominican Republic|List of Notable Dominicans (Dominican Republic)]] *[[List of Haitians|List of Notable Haitians]] *[[List of Bahamians|List of Notable Bahamians]] *[[List of Jamaicans|List of Notable Jamaicans]] *[[Taínos]] *[[Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center]] {{clr}}

page.title: List of active separatist movements in Oceania

revision.comment: rv edit by disruptive vandal [[Special:Contributions/2a02:c7f:1201:8700:3da4:7242:8b36:ca1a|2a02:c7f:1201:8700:3da4:7242:8b36:ca1a]], who didn't even string a sentence together
revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=March 2008}}
This is a '''list of currently active [[Separatism|separatist]] movements in [[Oceania]]'''. Separatism includes [[autonomism]] and [[secession]]ism. What is and is not considered an autonomist or secessionist movement is sometimes contentious. Entries on this list must meet three criteria: #They are active movements with living, active members. #They are seeking greater autonomy or self-determination for a geographic region (as opposed to personal autonomy). #They are the citizen/peoples of the conflict area.
Under each region listed is one or more of the following (except for The United States which only has the last one): *''De facto'' state: for regions with ''[[de facto]]'' autonomy from the government *Proposed state: proposed name for a seceding [[sovereign state]] *Proposed autonomous area: for movements toward greater [[Autonomous area|autonomy for an area]] but not outright secession **''De facto'' autonomous government: for governments with ''de facto'' autonomous control over a region **Government-in-exile: for a [[Government in exile|government based outside of the region in question]], with or without control **Political party (or parties): for [[Political party|political parties]] involved in a political system to push for autonomy or secession **Militant organisation(s): for armed organisations **Advocacy group(s): for [[Advocacy group|non-belligerent, non-politically participatory entities]] **[[Ethnic]]/[[ethno-religious]]/[[racial]]/[[Regionalism (politics)|regional]]/[[Religious denomination|religious]] group(s)
==Australia== {{flag|Australia}}
* Ethnic group: [[Indigenous Australians]] ** Proposed state: Various ** Pressure groups: [[Aboriginal Tent Embassy]], [[Murrawarri Republic]] [[Torres Strait Islands]] * Ethnic group: [[Torres Strait Islanders]] ** Proposed state: [[Torres Strait Islands]]<ref>Sarah Elks (15 October 2011). [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/indigenous/for-mabos-sake-let-my-island-home-go-torres-strait-elder-george-mye/story-fn9hm1pm-1226167158932 For Mabo's sake, let my island home go: Torres Strait elder George Mye]. ''The Australian''. News Limited. Retrieved on 25 April 2012.</ref><ref>Larine Statham (17 October 2011). [http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/progress-for-torres-strait-independence/story-fn6ck2c6-1226168521353 Progress for Torres Strait independence]. ''Courier Mail''. Queensland Newspapers. Retrieved on 25 April 2012.</ref><ref>(5 August 2009). [http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/mp-supports-torres-strait-independence/story-e6frfku0-1225758260046 MP supports Torres Strait independence]. news.com.au. News Limited. Retrieved on 25 April 2012.</ref> {{flag|Norfolk Island}} * Ethnic group: Norfolk Islanders **Proposed state: [[Politics of Norfolk Island#Independence|Norfolk Island]] {{flag|Western Australia}} *Proposed state: [[Secessionism in Western Australia|Western Australia]] {{flag|Tasmania}} *Proposed state: [[Secessionism in Tasmania|Tasmania]] **Pressure group: First Party of Tasmania
==Chile== *{{flag|Easter Island|name=Rapa Nui}} (Easter Island)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nativevillage.org/Archives/2004/Feb%204%20News/Native%20Village%20News%20,%20Feb%204%20,%202004,I%20127%20V1.htm |title=Native Village News |publisher=Nativevillage.org |date= |accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hectortobar.com/easterisland |title=easterisland - www |publisher=Hectortobar.com |date=2004-01-28}}</ref> **Ethnic group: [[Rapa Nui people|Rapa Nui]]
==Fiji== {{flagicon image|Flag of Rotuma (1987-1988).svg}} [[Rotuma]]
* Ethnic group: [[Rotumans|Rotuman]] **Proposed state: [[Rotuma]]
==France== *{{flag|French Polynesia}} ** Political party: [[Tavini Huiraatira]] * [[Moorea]] ** Proposed state: [[Republic of Hau Pakumoto]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geocurrents.info/geopolitics/the-republic-of-hau-pakumoto|title=The Republic of Hau Pakumoto?|work=GeoCurrents|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> *{{flag|New Caledonia}} ** Political party: [[Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front]] ([[Caledonian Union]], [[Party of Kanak Liberation]]), [[Kanak Socialist Liberation]], [[Labour Party (New Caledonia)|Labour Party]], [[Union of Pro-Independence Co-operation Committees]], [[Renewed Caledonian Union]] ** Proposed state: [[Kanaky]]
==Indonesia== {{See also|List of active separatist movements in Asia#Indonesia}}
[[Aceh]] *Proposed state: [[File:Flag of Aceh.svg|22x20px|border]] [[Aceh|Republic of Aceh]] **Militant organisation: [[Free Aceh Movement]] (negotiated peace with the Indonesian government in 2005, and now it is a civil movement, but the separatism still has supporters)
[[Kalimantan]] * Proposed state: [[File:Flag of Kalimantan Borneo.png|22x20px|border]] [[Kalimantan Borneo]] or {{flag|Malaysia}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribunnews.com/nasional/2011/08/04/perhatian-buruk-warga-perbatasan-ancam-kibarkan-bendera-malaysia|title=Perhatian Buruk! Warga Perbatasan Ancam Kibarkan Bendera Malaysia|publisher=Tribun News|date=4 August 2011|accessdate=4 July 2014|language=Indonesian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itoday.co.id/politik/duh-wni-di-perbatasan-ancam-gabung-ke-malaysia?q=/politik/7351-duh-wni-di-perbatasan-ancam-gabung-ke-malaysia|title=Duh, WNI di Perbatasan Ancam Gabung ke Malaysia|publisher=I Today|date=1 May 2012|accessdate=4 July 2014|language=Indonesian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpnn.com/index.php?mib=berita.detail&id=91667|title=Sejumlah Kecamatan Perbatasan Ingin Gabung Malaysia|publisher=JPNN|date=11 May 2011|accessdate=4 July 2014|language=Indonesian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jawaban.com/index.php/news/detail/id/91/news/110512133720/limit/0/Warga-Sebatik-Ingin-Gabung-ke-Malaysia-NKRI-Diambang-Kehancuran|title=Warga Sebatik Ingin Gabung ke Malaysia, NKRI Diambang Kehancuran?|publisher=Jawaban News|date=12 May 2011|accessdate=4 July 2014|language=Indonesian}}</ref>
[[Maluku Islands|South Moluccas]] *Proposed state: [[File:Flag of South Moluccas.svg|22x20px|border]] [[Republic of South Maluku|South Moluccas]] **Government-in-exile: [[Republik Maluku Selatan]] (member of the [[Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization]]) **Advocacy group: [[Maluku Sovereignty Front]]
[[North Sulawesi|Minahasa]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indonesiamatters.com/758/minahasa-nationalism/|title=Minahasa Nationalism|work=Indonesia Matters|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasty-bali.org/sulawesi-separatists.html|title=Christian Sulawesi (Minahasa) seeks independence from Muslim Indonesia|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> * Proposed state:[[File:Minahasa vlag Flag.jpg|22x20px|border]] Gerakan Kemerdekaan Minahasa
[[West Papua (region)|West Papua]] *Proposed state: [[File:Morning Star flag.svg|22x20px|border]] [[Republic of West Papua]] or unification with {{flag|Papua New Guinea}} *Militant organisation: [[Free Papua Movement]]
[[Riau]]{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} *Proposed state: [[File:Flag of Riau Independists.svg|22x20px|border]] [[Riau]]
[[West Timor]] * Proposed state: unification with {{flag|East Timor}}
==Kiribati== * [[Banaba Island]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.banaban.com/ |title=Banaba - Our Homeland |publisher=Abara Banaba |accessdate=2009-04-10}}</ref>
==New Zealand== {{see also|Republicanism in New Zealand}}
*{{flagicon image|Flag of the Cook Islands.svg}} [[Cook Islands]] ** Proposed state: [[Sovereign Kingdom of the Cook Islands]] ** Initiative by the Cook Islands [[Ariki]] which considers both the Cook Islands' previous status as a British protectorate and its current status as associated state of New Zealand to be illegitimate. Aims to set up the Cook Islands as a sovereign state independent of both the United Kingdom and New Zealand.<ref>http://www.sovereigncookislands.info/img/dummies/Mr%20Joe%20Legg%2003.pdf</ref> *{{flagicon image|Tino Rangatiratanga Maori sovereignty movement flag.svg}} [[Māori people]] ** {{Main|Māori protest movement}} ** Political parties: [[Māori Party]], [[Mana Party (New Zealand)|Mana Party]] **Proposed state: [[New Zealand|Republic of New Zealand]] *{{flagicon image|Nelson flag.svg}} [[Nelson Province|Nelson]] ** Pressure groups: [[United Nelsonia]]<ref>http://nelsonweekly.co.nz/2017/07/groups-dark-ideology-causes-concern/</ref> **Proposed state: [[Nelson Province|Nelsonia]] *{{flagicon image|Tino Rangatiratanga Maori sovereignty movement flag.svg}} [[Ngāi Tūhoe]] (Māori [[iwi]], northeastern North Island) **Proposed state: [[Ngāi Tūhoe|Tūhoe Nation]] *{{flagicon image|Flag_of_Otago.svg}} [[Otago]] ** Pressure groups: [[Otago Separatism Movement]] **Proposed state: [[Otago Province|Otago]] *{{flagicon image|Proposed New Zealand South Island flag.svg}} [[South Island]] ** {{Main|South Island nationalism}} ** Political parties: [[NZ South Island Party|South Island Party]] ** Pressure groups: [[South Island Independence Movement]]<ref>https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/happen-south-island-independence-movement-vows-break-away</ref> **Proposed state: [[New Munster Province|New Munster]] **Proposed autonomous region: [[New Munster Province]]
==Papua New Guinea== *{{flag|Bougainville}} (member of the [[Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization]]) ** Political party: [[Bougainville Revolutionary Army]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-World-Insurgency-and-Terrorism/Bougainville-Revolutionary-Army-BRA-Papua-New-Guinea.html |title=Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA) (Papua New Guinea), GROUPS - ASIA - DORMANT |publisher=Jane's Information Group |accessdate=2009-04-10}}</ref> *[[Bougainville Island|Bougainville]] & [[Twin Kingdom of Papa'ala and Me'ekamui]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourbougainville.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/The-Real-Story-of-Bougainville-Islands-2012.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124070808/http://www.ourbougainville.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/The-Real-Story-of-Bougainville-Islands-2012.pdf |archivedate=2013-01-24 |df= }}</ref> ** Political group: [[Triune Government of Bougainville]] *{{flag|New Ireland}} ** Proposed autonomous province: New Ireland<ref>http://www.thenational.com.pg/anis-shares-vision-autonomy-new-ireland/</ref>
==United States== {{See also|List of active separatist movements in North America#United States}}
[[File:Flag of Hawaii.svg|22px|border]] [[Hawaii]] {{Main|Hawaiian sovereignty movement}} *Ethnic group: [[Native Hawaiians]] **Pressure groups (s): [[Nation of Hawaiʻi (organization)]], [[Office of Hawaiian Affairs]], Ka Lāhui Hawaiʻi (The purpose of these organizations and The Hawaiian Sovereignty Movement is to create Native Hawaiian nations within the State of Hawaii equal to Native American nations, or to obtain complete independence from the USA).
==Vanuatu== * [[Malekula]] ** Proposed state: [[N'Makiaute]] * Northern islands ** Proposed state: [[Federation Na Griamel]]
==See also== *[[List of active separatist movements]] *[[List of historical separatist movements]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Separatist movements per continent}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Active Separatist Movements In Oceania, List Of}} [[Category:Oceania-related lists|Separatist Movements, Active]] [[Category:Disputed territories in Oceania|Separatist Movements In Oceania, Active]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations| Oceania]] [[Category:Society-related lists|Separatist Movements In Oceania, Active]]

revision.text:
[[File:Chile in its region.svg|thumb|upright=1.2|Location of Chile]] This is a '''list of [[butterflies]] of [[Chile]]'''. About 200 species are known from Chile.<ref>[http://www.insectos.cl/listas/index_lepidoptera.php insectos.cl] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327061641/http://www.insectos.cl/listas/index_lepidoptera.php |date=2013-03-27 }}</ref>
==Hesperiidae==
===Pyrginae=== *''[[Urbanus dorantes|Urbanus dorantes dorantes]]'' *''[[Urbanus proteus|Urbanus proteus proteus]]'' *''[[Polytrix octomaculatus|Polytrix octomaculatus octumaculatus]]'' *''[[Pyrgus barrosi]]'' *''[[Pyrgus bochoris|Pyrgus bochoris trisignatus]]'' *''[[Pyrgus communis|Pyrgus communis chloe]]'' *''[[Pyrgus fides]]'' *''[[Pyrgus limbata|Pyrgus limbata limbata]]'' *''[[Pyrgus notatus|Pyrgus notatus notatus]]'' *''[[Pyrgus notatus|Pyrgus notatus valdivianus]]'' *''[[Pyrgus oileus|Pyrgus oileus orcus]]'' *''[[Heliopyrgus americanus|Heliopyrgus americanus americanus]]'' *''[[Erynnis funeralis]]''
===Hesperiinae=== *''[[Butleria flavomaculata|Butleria flavomaculata flavomaculata]]'' *''[[Butleria flavomaculata|Butleria flavomaculata valdiviana]]'' *''[[Butleria flavomaculata|Butleria flavomaculata tristriata]]'' *''[[Butleria paniscoides|Butleria paniscoides paniscoides]]'' *''[[Butleria paniscoides|Butleria paniscoides polyspila]]'' *''[[Butleria elwesi]]'' *''[[Butleria quilla]]'' *''[[Butleria fruticolens]]'' *''[[Butleria sotoi]]'' *''[[Butleria philippi]]'' *''[[Butleria bisexguttata]]'' *''[[Argopteron aureipennis]]'' *''[[Argopteron aureum]]'' *''[[Argopteron puelmae]]'' *''[[Hylephila ancora]]'' *''[[Hylephila boulleti|Hylephila boulleti boulleti]]'' *''[[Hylephila fasciolata]]'' *''[[Hylephila isonira|Hylephila isonira mima]]'' *''[[Hylephila phyleus|Hylephila phyleus bisistrigata]]'' *''[[Hylephila signata]]'' *''[[Hylephila venusta|Hylephila venusta venusta]]'' *''[[Hylephila venusta|Hylephila venusta haywardi]]'' *''[[Lerodea gracia]]'' *''[[Lerodea eufala]]'' *''[[Quinta canae]]'' *''[[Calpodes ethlius]]'' *''[[Nyctelius nyctelius|Nyctelius nyctelius nyctelius]]''
==Pieridae==
===Coliadinae=== *''[[Colias flaveola|Colias flaveola flaveola]]'' *''[[Colias flaveola|Colias flaveola mendozina]]'' *''[[Colias flaveola|Colias flaveola blameyi]]'' *''[[Colias flaveola|Colias flaveola weberbaueri]]'' *''[[Colias lesbia|Colias lesbia lesbia]]'' *''[[Colias vauthierii|Colias vauthierii vauthierii]]'' *''[[Colias vauthierii|Colias vauthierii cuninghami]]'' *''[[Zerene caesonia|Zerene caesonia caesonides]]'' *''[[Phoebis sennae|Phoebis sennae amphitrite]]'' *''[[Terias deva|Terias deva chilensis]]'' *''[[Teriocolias zelia|Teriocolias zelia kuscheli]]''
===Pierinae=== *''[[Eroessa chilensis]]'' *''[[Mathania leucothea]]'' *''[[Pieris brassicae]]'' *''[[Tatochila distincta|Tatochila distincta fieldi]]'' *''[[Tatochila mariae]]'' *''[[Tatochila inversa|Tatochila inversa razmilici]]'' *''[[Tatochila autodice|Tatochila autodice blanchardi]]'' *''[[Tatochila autodice|Tatochila authodice ernestae]]'' *''[[Tatochila mercedis|Tatochila mercedis mercedis]]'' *''[[Tatochila mercedis|Tatochila mercedis sterodice]]'' *''[[Tatochila mercedis|Tatochila mercedis macrodice]]'' *''[[Tatochila theodice|Tatochila theodice theodice]]'' *''[[Tatochila theodice|Tatochila theodice gymnodice]]'' *''[[Hypsochila galactodice]]'' *''[[Hypsochila huemul]]'' *''[[Hypsochila penai]]'' *''[[Hypsochila argyrodice]]'' *''[[Hypsochila wagenknechti|Hypsochila wagenknechti wagenknechti]]'' *''[[Hypsochila wagenknechti|Hypsochila wagenknechti sulfurodice]]'' *''[[Hypsochila microdice]]'' *''[[Phulia nymphula|Phulia nymphula nymphula]]'' *''[[Pierphulia rosea|Pierphulia rosea rosea]]'' *''[[Pierphulia rosea|Pierphulia rosea maria]]'' *''[[Pierphulia isabella]]'' *''[[Infraphulia ilyodes]]''
==Papilionidae== *''[[Battus polydamas|Battus polydamas archidamas]]''
==Lycaenidae==
===Theclinae=== *''[[Strymon eurytulus]]'' *''[[Strymon davara|Strymon davara joannisi]]'' *''[[Strymon sapota]]'' *''[[Strymon crambusa]]'' *''[[Strymon peristictos]]'' *''[[Strymon daraba]]'' *''[[Ministrymon azia]]'' *''[[Chlorostrymon kuscheli]]'' *''[[Chlorostrymon larancagua]]'' *''[[Chlorostrymon chileana]]'' *''[[Tergissima shargeli]]'' *''[[Calycopis valparaiso]]'' *''[[Eiseliana flavaria]]'' *''[[Eiseliana rojasi]]'' *''[[Eiseliana bicolor]]'' *''[[Eiseliana probabila]]'' *''[[Heoda wagenknechti]]'' *''[[Heoda suprema]]'' *''[[Heoda shapiroi]]'' *''[[Heoda atacama]]'' *''[[Heoda nivea]]'' *''[[Heoda erani]]'' *''[[Abloxurina muela|Abloxurina muela putreensis]]'' *''[[Pontirama coquimbiensis]]'' *''[[Rhamma chilensis]]'' *''[[Shapiroana herrerai]]'' *''[[Rekoa palegon cyrriana]]'' *''[[Penaincisalia oribata]]'' *''[[Penaincisalia patagonaevaga]]''
===Polymmatinae=== *''[[Itylos titicaca]]'' *''[[Hemiargus ramon]]'' *''[[Nabokovia faga]]'' *''[[Nabokovia ada]]'' *''[[Leptotes trigemmatus]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia collina]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia beyamini]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia Iyrnessa]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia hazeorum]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia clarea]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia plumbea]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia annamaria]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia scintilla]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia vera]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia chilensis]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia lanin]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia andina]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia avishai]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia sibylla]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia penai]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia aureliana]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia oligocyanea]]'' *''[[Pseudolucia argentina]]'' *''[[Madeleinea ludrica]]'' *''[[Madeleinea pelorias]]'' *''[[Madeleinea sigal]]''
==Nymphalidae==
===Danainae=== *''[[Danaus plexipus|Danaus plexipus erippus]]''
